biogHists.text:
The Canadian Broadcasting Corporation was formed on 2 November 1936 consisting of two radio networks: Trans-Canada (English) and the French network. In 1952 two television stations began broadcasting in Toronto and Montreal.

From the description of Canadian Broadcasting Corporation collection. 1929-[195-]. (McMaster University). WorldCat record id: 181806794

                     </role>

                  <titleInfo>
                     <title>Social and general supplementary correspondence C : 1949. 1950 June 27 - Dec. 24.</title>
                  </titleInfo>
                  <abstract>Correspondence with: the Cape Breton Island Gaelic Foundation inviting Beaverbrook to speak at a ceremony to pay tribute to Norman MacLeod; Annie Cool and Clarence Corbett, former Newcastle acquaintances; D.G. Creighton, professor of history at University of Toronto regarding his biography of John A. MacDonald; the Canadian Broadcasting Corporation requesting transcripts of a Maritime Gardener radio programme, and of Beaverbrook's speech given at the Royal Winter Fair 1950; M. Helen Cameron and Gordon Cassidy who were N.B. teachers chosen to tour the U.K. in 1951; Dr. A. Pierce Crocket of Fredericton regarding Beaverbrook's asthma. </abstract>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>University of New Brunswick, Fredericton</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/rps">Repository</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
               </mods>
            </objectXMLWrap>

resource.title: Learned Hand papers, 1840-1961
resource.abstract: Materials relating to Hand's private and public life, his activities as an alumnus of Harvard University, his friendship with Felix Frankfurter, and to the Hand family. Includes material on the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of New York and the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit, New York City; information on the Progressive movement (1909-1914) and the beginnings of the New Republic and its early staff; and transcripts of oral-history interviews conducted by Gerald Gunther of Stanford Law School and others, of Judge Hand, his family and associates.
resource.extent: 235 MSS boxes; 18 Paige boxes; 116.6 linear ft.
resource.displayEntry: Hand, Learned, 1872-1961. Papers, 1840-1961

nameEntries.original: Harvard Law School Library, Harvard University.

                  <titleInfo>
                     <title>Papers by or about B. Traven, 1950-1977.</title>
                  </titleInfo>
                  <abstract>The bulk of the collection is correspondence of Sanora Babb Howe, an author, editor at the California Quarterly, and friend of Traven. The letters concern the rights to a Traven story adapted for radio and television by Ted Allan, a playwright who worked for the Canadian Broadcasting Corporation. Traven would not negotiate directly with Allan or the CBC. Also contains manuscripts by Traven with annotations by Howe and others, of his Indian mass industry and The uninvited guest. </abstract>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Harvard University</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/rps">Repository</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
               </mods>
            </objectXMLWrap>

<objectXMLWrap>
               <did xmlns="urn:isbn:1-931666-22-9">
                  <unittitle>Nicolas Slonimsky Collection<unitdate>1873-1997</unitdate>
                     <unitdate>(bulk 1920-1990)</unitdate>
                  </unittitle>
                  <unitid>ML31.S6</unitid>
                  <origination>
                     <persname>Slonimsky, Nicolas, 1894-1995</persname>
                  </origination>
                  <physdesc>
                     <extent>circa 118,600 items</extent>
                     <extent>354 boxes</extent>
                     <extent>500 linear feet</extent>
                  </physdesc>
                  <langmaterial>Collection material in <language>English</language>
                  </langmaterial>
                  <repository>
                     <corpname>
                        <subarea>Music Division</subarea> Library of Congress</corpname>
                     <address>
                        <addressline>Washington, D.C.</addressline>
                     </address>
                  </repository>
                  <abstract>Collection contains materials collected by Slonimsky throughout his lifetime that document his life and work as musicologist, composer, conductor, lecturer and author. Included are personal biographical materials; Slonimsky's writings (drafts, typescripts, reprints, etc.) of newspaper, periodical, journal, and magazine articles, record liner notes, radio broadcasts, and talks, published and unpublished; music composed by Slonimsky, manuscript and printed; concert programs; correspondence, among many others, with Henry Cowell, Alexandre Gretchaninoff, Roy Harris, Charles Ives, and Edgar Varèse; biographical materials on composers and performers mosly generated when Slonimsky was editing Baker's and The international cyclopedia; music collected by Slonimsky, manuscript and printed and multi-composer collections; among the manuscripts are many short holographic works and fragments; scrapbooks; and iconographical material, such as family photographs an those of composers and musicians from the former Soviet Union, as well as little known musicians from the United States and elsewhere.</abstract>
               </did>
            </objectXMLWrap>
resource.title: Nicolas Slonimsky Collection 1873-1997 (bulk 1920-1990)
resource.abstract: Collection contains materials collected by Slonimsky throughout his lifetime that document his life and work as musicologist, composer, conductor, lecturer and author. Included are personal biographical materials; Slonimsky's writings (drafts, typescripts, reprints, etc.) of newspaper, periodical, journal, and magazine articles, record liner notes, radio broadcasts, and talks, published and unpublished; music composed by Slonimsky, manuscript and printed; concert programs; correspondence, among many others, with Henry Cowell, Alexandre Gretchaninoff, Roy Harris, Charles Ives, and Edgar Varèse; biographical materials on composers and performers mosly generated when Slonimsky was editing Baker's and The international cyclopedia; music collected by Slonimsky, manuscript and printed and multi-composer collections; among the manuscripts are many short holographic works and fragments; scrapbooks; and iconographical material, such as family photographs an those of composers and musicians from the former Soviet Union, as well as little known musicians from the United States and elsewhere.
resource.displayEntry: Nicolas Slonimsky Collection, 1873-1997, (bulk 1920-1990)

                     <title>R.W. Carbert collection (University of Guelph). 1935- 1989.</title>
                  </titleInfo>
                  <abstract>The collection consists of research material and reports, newspaper articles and clippings, photographs, correspondence, farm broadcasting and farm television information, history of agriculture, speeches and papers, meeting minutes, milk production and information; material related to log houses, octagonal buildings, silos, Huron County Pioneer Museum; Ontario Agricultural Museum buildings, barns, landscaping. Oversize files contain blueprints and plans of various buildings of the Ontario Agricultural Museum; larger photographs of log cutting, threshing, and cow milking demonstrations, Macdonald Manufacturing Co. steam engine, Bucyrus bulldozer, and other machinery displays; Century Soap Co. poster. </abstract>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>University of Guelph</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/rps">Repository</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
               </mods>
            </objectXMLWrap>

Oversize files contain blueprints and plans of various buildings of the Ontario Agricultural Museum; larger photographs of log cutting, threshing, and cow milking demonstrations, Macdonald Manufacturing Co. steam engine, Bucyrus bulldozer, and other machinery displays; Century Soap Co. poster.

                  <recordInfo>

                     <recordContentSource>ISIL:OCLC-LCY</recordContentSource>
                  </recordInfo>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Rogers, Fred.</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/cre">Creator</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
                  <titleInfo>
                     <title>[Letter, 1958 Sept. 23 : to Stanley Cox].</title>
                  </titleInfo>
                  <abstract>Fred Rogers thanks the CBC for considering his script, "Josephine the Giraffe," but understands that they are too busy to produce the musical.  Rogers describes a new program that he is producing at WQED called "The Prince." </abstract>
                  <name>

                  </name>
                  <titleInfo>
                     <title>Mercury collection, 1954-1990 and undated (inclusive), 1969-1983 (bulk.)</title>
                  </titleInfo>
                  <abstract>The Mercury collection of Marion Lamm was acquired in its entirety in 1997 as a gift from Rochelle Lamm Wallach. The Marion Lamm Mercury Collection consists of the library/research collection gathered by Marion Lamm beginning in the early 1970's and spanning to the lated 1980's. It is believed that Marion began collecting related materials in order to sufficiently document the claim brought against Dryden Chemicals, Limited and Dryden Pulp and Paper Company. Later the collection became a storehouse for researchers interested in the mercury pollution case. Documents were used at the Lamm's home where they were kept in the "library" as well as copied and sent to parties unable to travel to the Lamm's home. Although not certain, Marion may have collected materials herself from various libraries, some materials were sent to her by others who knew of her collection, while they have also hired a person to collect documentation from various sources. Topics relate to mercury poisoning (Minamata disease), tourism, governmental action, tourism reactions, governmental research, scientific research, socio-economic effects of mercury poisoning on Ojibway Indians, effects of mercury poisoning on Japanese living in Minamata Bay, Japan, health effects of mercury poisoning, industries responsible for pollution, uses of industrial mercury Materials represented are correspondence; clippings; reports; scientific research; wrtitings; governmental statements and actions; photographs; legal documents; ephemera; reprints; audiotapes; scrapbooks </abstract>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Unknown</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/rps">Repository</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
               </mods>
            </objectXMLWrap>

<objectXMLWrap>
               <mods xmlns="http://www.loc.gov/mods/v3">
                  <recordInfo>
                     <recordOrigin>WorldCat:144613290</recordOrigin>
                     <recordContentSource>ISIL:OCLC-AHJ</recordContentSource>
                  </recordInfo>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Israel, Charles E.</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/cre">Creator</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
                  <titleInfo>
                     <title>Charles E. Israel papers, 1877-1995, (bulk 1937-1995)</title>
                  </titleInfo>
                  <abstract>Collection contains Charles E. Israel's annotated television  manuscripts (originals and copies), including those for the series "House of Pride" and "The Newcomers" and the television movies "Louisiana" and "Mayflower Madam".  Collection also contains Israel's annotated movie manuscripts (originals and copies), including those for his instructional films (including "Inmate Training Films"), and feature films (including "The Mark" and "Angela").  A number of Israel's book manuscripts, including "Shadow on the Wall" and "Son's Eye", are also found in this collection.  Collection also holds correspondence (business and personal), subject files (which contain correspondence, clippings, manuscripts, notes, financial documents, and photographs), photographs (of Israel and his family, actors, actresses, and his travels), legal files, financial files, and mimeographed copies of his radio scripts (including those for "Tales of the Texas Rangers" and "CBC Stage").  Several Beta videotapes of Israel's works (including "Louisiana" and "Mayflower Madam"), and several unidentified audio cassette tapes are in this collection as well. </abstract>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>University of Wyoming, American Heritage Center</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/rps">Repository</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
               </mods>
            </objectXMLWrap>

                     <namePart>Cavendish, Andrew Robert Buxton, Duke of Devonshire, 1920-</namePart>

                     <namePart>London Express and Feature News Service.</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/cre">Creator</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
                  <titleInfo>
                     <title>Correspondence with Michael Wardell : August 1962-December 1963. 1962 Aug. 2 - Dec. 28.</title>
                  </titleInfo>
                  <abstract>Letters, telegrams, memos, soundscribers and sketch concerning: Diefenbaker--his health and his views on the Common Market, Atlantic Development Board, etc.; Wardell's opinion on the Common Market and its effect on Canada; cancellation of liquor advertising in New Brunswick by the Liquor Commission and Wardell's allegation that this was politically motivated; Robichaud's new Liqour Control Act; walking sticks sent to Joey Smallwood; cancellation of advertising in the Atlantic Advocate by Moosehead and Olands Breweries; Beaverbrook supplies advertising in the Atlantic Advocate for the art gallery (costs included) to replace brewery ads; 1961 census figures for Northumberland County including French/English breakdown; Eric Bowater's death; setting up of Atlantic Development Board and naming of Wardell as Chairman; New Brunswick Symphony Orchestra; syndication of Lady's Dunn picture of the Queen; news of the birth of Lady Jean's baby; relationship between Robert N. Thompson and Diefenbaker; (CONTINUES). (CONTINUED) CBC setting up radio and television stations in Fredericton and the possibility of using the new theatre as a studio; Wardell's prediction that Robichaud would be beaten in the next election; Edwy Cooke's exhibition of paintings at UNB's Memorial Hall and the desire of the Friends of the Beaverbrook Art Gallery to purchase "Profile of a City" for addition to Beaverbrook's Collection; shipment, sale and custom duty on the "Divine Propagandist"; general business of Atlantic Advocate; Wardell's Canadian citizenship; problems encountered at the art gallery due to a leaking roof; J. Leonard O'Brien's friendship with Beaverbrook; Wardell's Christmas visit to Cherkley; sales of the book, "How to be Kind" and A.W. Trueman and the Canada Council. Included in the file are draft copies and a final copy of Wardell's speech given at the Mount Allison 1962 Summer Institute (held Aug. 16-18), "Canada, the Commonwealth and the Common Market." </abstract>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>University of New Brunswick, Fredericton</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/rps">Repository</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
               </mods>
            </objectXMLWrap>

Thompson and Diefenbaker; (CONTINUES). (CONTINUED) CBC setting up radio and television stations in Fredericton and the possibility of using the new theatre as a studio; Wardell's prediction that Robichaud would be beaten in the next election; Edwy Cooke's exhibition of paintings at UNB's Memorial Hall and the desire of the Friends of the Beaverbrook Art Gallery to purchase "Profile of a City" for addition to Beaverbrook's Collection; shipment, sale and custom duty on the "Divine Propagandist"; general business of Atlantic Advocate; Wardell's Canadian citizenship; problems encountered at the art gallery due to a leaking roof; J. Leonard O'Brien's friendship with Beaverbrook; Wardell's Christmas visit to Cherkley; sales of the book, "How to be Kind" and A.W. Trueman and the Canada Council. Included in the file are draft copies and a final copy of Wardell's speech given at the Mount Allison 1962 Summer Institute (held Aug. 16-18), "Canada, the Commonwealth and the Common Market."
resource.displayEntry: Wardell, Michael. Correspondence with Michael Wardell : August 1962-December 1963.

                     <persname>Sherred, T.L. (1915-1985)</persname>

                  <unittitle>Papers of T.L. Sherred, 1966-1989</unittitle>
                  <unitdate>1966-1989</unitdate>
                  <langmaterial>
                     <language>English </language>
                  </langmaterial>
                  <physdesc>
                     <extent>4.75 linear feet (12 boxes) </extent>
                  </physdesc>
                  <abstract>Grand Rapids, Michigan native Thomas L. Sherred (1915-1985) was a writer of science fiction. His papers for the period of 1966-1989 reflect his science fiction writing but primarily consist of correspondence with other authors, including Lloyd Biggle, Jr, Howard DeVore, and Virginia Kidd. It also includes working manuscripts for his novel <emph>Alien Island</emph> and manuscripts of short stories. 
</abstract>
                  <unitid>MS 81</unitid>
                  <unitid>MS 82</unitid>
                  <unitid>MS 89</unitid>
                  <unitid>MS 253</unitid>
                  <physloc>Contact Spencer Library Reader Services (Library Annex)</physloc>
               </did>
            </objectXMLWrap>

resource.title: Edwin Way Teale Papers undated, 1799-1995
resource.abstract: Edwin Way Teale, Connecticut-based naturalist, was the author of thirty-two books. His papers include field notes and drafts for each of his books, early childhood writings, professional writings for magazines, newspapers and book reviews, correspondence- both personal and professional, personal and family documents, scrapbooks, and memorabilia, as well as his photographs (prints, negatives, and transparencies) and his personal library. There is also one box of original John Burroughs material Teale collected over the years.
resource.displayEntry: Teale, Edwin Way, 1899-1980. Papers, 1799-1995 and undated

nameEntries.original: Archives and Special Collections at the Thomas J. Dodd Research Center, University of Connecticut Libraries

resourceRelations.content: Edwin Way Teale Papers, undated, 1799-1995.

                  </titleInfo>
                  <abstract>Topics include: gas lamps and a sundial for the Newcastle Town Square; Mr. Trythall's progress at recording folk songs and his composition of a regimental march; Battle Honours for the Royal New Brunswick Regiment; Beaverbrook's brief description of his birthplace at Maple, Ont. {26222}; French books for Mr. Cayouette and the students at Eel River Crossing; paving the playground of the school at Beaverbrook, N.B.; progress of the Art Gallery Act in the legislature; Tweedie's inspection of various projects at Newcastle; plans to set up an Archives in the Old Officers' Quarters after the Legion vacates the building; Beaverbrook's plans to entertain Miss Alicia Patterson in N.B. (publisher of Newsday, New York and trustee of the Chicago Tribune). </abstract>

                     <role>

<objectXMLWrap>
               <mods xmlns="http://www.loc.gov/mods/v3">
                  <recordInfo>
                     <recordOrigin>WorldCat:60206737</recordOrigin>
                     <recordContentSource>ISIL:OCLC-UAA</recordContentSource>
                  </recordInfo>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Pedersen, Ted (Theodore), 1905-1990.</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/cre">Creator</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Hodge, Carroll.</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/cre">Creator</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Canadian Broadcasting Corporation.</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/cre">Creator</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>KAKM (Television station : Anchorage, Alaska)</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/cre">Creator</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
                  <titleInfo>
                     <title>Videocassettes and papers, 1914-1915, 1978, 1983.</title>
                  </titleInfo>
                  <abstract>The collection consists of videocassette copies of original motion picture film and television productions concerning the life of Theodore Pedersen and his father Captain Christian T. Pedersen, published articles about Theodore Pedersen, and a photograph of his grave marker. The collection contains four different videocassettes. The first is of an early motion picture film with titles, held at the National Archives, documenting a trip aboard Captain Christian T. Pedersen's ship, the whaler Herman, in about 1914-1915 (53 minutes). The second is of a selection of episodes of the Canadian Broadcasting Corporation, British Columbia documentary television series, The Northerners, from 1978 (109 minutes). The episodes examine arctic lifestyles, transportation, and traders. In three segments from these episodes, Ted Pedersen speaks about his friendship with Captain Henry Larsen, helps start the engine of the dry-docked schooner Fox, once owned by Captain Christian T. Pedersen, and talks about life aboard his father's trading vessels, showing film footage he took during a trading voyage in 1935. The third is a 1983 KAKM public television documentary entitled "Ted," on Ted Pedersen's life (29 minutes). The documentary includes early footage taken by Pedersen in the arctic. The fourth is a working tape from the documentary "Ted," of Pedersen's film footage with voiceover of producer Carroll Hodge interviewing him about the footage and about his father (62 minutes). </abstract>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>UAA/APU Consortium Library</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/rps">Repository</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
               </mods>
            </objectXMLWrap>

resource.source:
<objectXMLWrap>
               <mods xmlns="http://www.loc.gov/mods/v3">
                  <recordInfo>
                     <recordOrigin>WorldCat:181806794</recordOrigin>
                     <recordContentSource>ISIL:OCLC-MUX</recordContentSource>
                  </recordInfo>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Canadian Broadcasting Corporation.</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/cre">Creator</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
                  <titleInfo>
                     <title>Canadian Broadcasting Corporation collection. 1929-[195-].</title>
                  </titleInfo>
                  <abstract>There have been three accruals. The first accrual consists of microfilmed scripts of dramas produced by the CBC. The original scripts were disposed of after microfilming. The majority of these scripts are of radio plays, although there are some which were produced on television. Dramatists include Fletcher Markle, W. O. Mitchell, Lister Sinclair, Joseph Schull, Pierre Berton, Len Peterson and George Salverson. The second accrual consists of printed materials: the texts of speeches broadcast, 1940-1941, and pamphlets printed by the CBC describing their programming from 1936 to 1943. The third accrual consists of 4 audio reels, containing a speech by the Rt. Hon. Arthur Meighen (1874-1960), Prime Minister of Canada, 1920-1921 and 1926, to the Canadian Club in 1936 with an introduction by W. A. Bishop. Researchers are also directed to the Jim Bannerman fonds for additional scripts, as well as the Pierre Berton, Austin Clarke, David Helwig and Leslie McFarlane fonds. </abstract>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>McMaster University</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/rps">Repository</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
               </mods>
            </objectXMLWrap>

                     <namePart>Solway, Larry.</namePart>
                     <role>

                     </role>
                  </name>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>National Film Board of Canada</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/cre">Creator</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Canadian Broadcasting Corporation</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/cre">Creator</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
                  <titleInfo>
                     <title>[Richard Gilbert collection] [multimedia]. [1959-1972]</title>
                  </titleInfo>
                  <abstract>A Man for all cities. A CBC Telescope 1971 production on Arthur Erickson, written and directed by Richard Gilbert. Filmed on location in Vancouver. One small scene on Simon Fraser University was removed from this copy. Looking South. A CBC production filmed in 1975 and telecast in 1976. A tribute to the United States during their bi-centenary. Directed by Richard Gilbert with Larry Solway as on-camera host and interviewer. Includes scene with John Portman shot in the lobby of the Atlanta Hyatt Hotel which he designed, and scene in the Church of Martin Luther King. Suburban living: six solutions. National Film Board of Canada production for CBC TV, filmed in 1959 and telecast in 1960. Written and directed by Richard Gilbert. Examines solutions to the problems of designing suburbs in six neighbourhoods, five abroad and one in North America. Shows homes and community areas, and notes importance of aesthetic considerations. Considers developments in England, at Harlow New Town, and the Alton Estate L.C.C., the Unité d'Habitation by Le Corbusier in Marseille, Pendrecht, Holland, Vallingby, Sweden and the Don Mills development in Ontario. Where it all began. CBC production shot in 1975 as tribute to the bi-centenary of the United States. Directed by Richard Gilbert with Larry Solway as on-camera host. Focuses on historical New England with views of Boston, Newport and Rhode Island architecture. </abstract>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Centre canadien d'architecture</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/rps">Repository</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
               </mods>
            </objectXMLWrap>

Directed by Richard Gilbert with Larry Solway as on-camera host and interviewer. Includes scene with John Portman shot in the lobby of the Atlanta Hyatt Hotel which he designed, and scene in the Church of Martin Luther King. Suburban living: six solutions.                         <addressline>New York Public Library for the Performing Arts, Dorothy and Lewis B. Cullman Center</addressline>
                        <addressline>40 Lincoln Center Plaza, New York, NY 10023-7498</addressline>

                  </repository>
                  <physdesc>
                     <extent>67 tape reels</extent>
                     <physfacet>analog</physfacet>
                     <dimensions>7 in.</dimensions>
                  </physdesc>
                  <abstract>The collection contains recordings of the radio programs which Diether wrote, including the series "The Life of Beethoven." In addition to the programs themselves, sound cues for the programs are included. The collection also contains appearences of Diether as a commentator on radio programs and intermission features from concert broadcasts. In addition to documentaries and commentary, there are recordings of concerts by the New York Mahlerites (today known as The Gustav Mahler Society of New York).</abstract>
               </did>
            </objectXMLWrap>

resource.source:
<objectXMLWrap>
               <did xmlns="urn:isbn:1-931666-22-9">
                  <unittitle>George P. Garrett Papers, 
		  <unitdate>1929-2008</unitdate>
                     <unitdate>(bulk 1960-2000)</unitdate>
                  </unittitle>
                  <origination>
                     <persname>Garrett, George P., 1929-2008</persname>
                  </origination>
                  <physdesc>
                     <extent>268 Linear Feet</extent>
                     <extent>177,929 Items</extent>
                  </physdesc>
                  <repository>
                     <corpname>Duke University. David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library</corpname>
                  </repository>
                  <physloc>For current information on
		  the location of these materials, please consult the
		  Library's online catalog.</physloc>
                  <langmaterial>
                     <language>English.</language>
                  </langmaterial>
                  <abstract>George P. Garrett (1929-2008) was a poet, editor, author, and professor of English.</abstract>
                  <abstract>The papers of George P. Garrett span the years 1929 to 2000 with the bulk of the material being dated between 1960 and 1990. The papers were initially collected and assembled by author, bibliographer, and publisher Stuart T. Wright. Wright published a number of Garrett's works at his Palaemon Press and also assembled the Stuart Wright Bibliographic Collection of George Garrett (see related materials held by the Rubenstein Library). Additional materials were received by the Library directly from George Garrett. The papers document Garrett's literary career as an author of novels, short stories, poetry, and dramatic works (including filmscripts) and the tremendous influence he had as an English professor and an editor on an entire generation of writers, particularly in the South. Correspondence with numerous authors, publishers, and educators offers much information about the history of 20th-century Southern literature, publishing, and literary education. The collection is divided into the Writings Series (with subseries of Writings by Garrett, Writings Edited by Garrett, Writings by Others, and Proofs); the Correspondence Series (with 5 subseries of alphabetically and chronologically arranged correspondence); the Audiovisual Material Series; and the Miscellaneous Papers Series.</abstract>
               </did>
            </objectXMLWrap>
resource.title: George P. Garrett Papers, 1929-2008 (bulk 1960-2000)
resource.abstract: George P. Garrett (1929-2008) was a poet, editor, author, and professor of English. The papers of George P. Garrett span the years 1929 to 2000 with the bulk of the material being dated between 1960 and 1990. The papers were initially collected and assembled by author, bibliographer, and publisher Stuart T. Wright. Wright published a number of Garrett's works at his Palaemon Press and also assembled the Stuart Wright Bibliographic Collection of George Garrett (see related materials held by the Rubenstein Library). Additional materials were received by the Library directly from George Garrett. The papers document Garrett's literary career as an author of novels, short stories, poetry, and dramatic works (including filmscripts) and the tremendous influence he had as an English professor and an editor on an entire generation of writers, particularly in the South. Correspondence with numerous authors, publishers, and educators offers much information about the history of 20th-century Southern literature, publishing, and literary education. The collection is divided into the Writings Series (with subseries of Writings by Garrett, Writings Edited by Garrett, Writings by Others, and Proofs); the Correspondence Series (with 5 subseries of alphabetically and chronologically arranged correspondence); the Audiovisual Material Series; and the Miscellaneous Papers Series.

<objectXMLWrap>
               <mods xmlns="http://www.loc.gov/mods/v3">
                  <recordInfo>
                     <recordOrigin>WorldCat:606459792</recordOrigin>
                     <recordContentSource>ISIL:OCLC-UBC</recordContentSource>
                  </recordInfo>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Plaunt, Alan Butterworth, 1904-1941.</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/cre">Creator</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
                  <titleInfo>
                     <title>Alan Plaunt fonds. 1930-1962.</title>
                  </titleInfo>
                  <abstract>The fonds consists of four series: Personal Papers, the Canadian Radio League, the Canadian Broadcasting Corporation, and Dorothy Plaunt Dyde. Fonds contains correspondence, financial records, subject files, clippings, reports, submissions, publicity material, and other documentary forms. The Plaunt correspondence contains a detailed record of the events surrounding the history of the Canadian Radio League, the Canadian Radio Broadcasting Commission (1932), and the Act creating the Canadian Broadcasting Corporation. </abstract>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>University of British Columbia Library</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/rps">Repository</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
               </mods>
            </objectXMLWrap>
resource.title: Alan Plaunt fonds. 1930-1962.
resource.abstract: The fonds consists of four series: Personal Papers, the Canadian Radio League, the Canadian Broadcasting Corporation, and Dorothy Plaunt Dyde. Fonds contains correspondence, financial records, subject files, clippings, reports, submissions, publicity material, and other documentary forms. The Plaunt correspondence contains a detailed record of the events surrounding the history of the Canadian Radio League, the Canadian Radio Broadcasting Commission (1932), and the Act creating the Canadian Broadcasting Corporation.
